nodes.title: I.2. Residential Structures in Other Locations: Religious and Elite Residences

nodes.body:
• Site name: Lungtsen PukLung bstan phug
  • Site number: B-33
  • Site typology: I.2a
  • Geographic coordinate (N. lat.): 31º 00.9΄
  • Geographic coordinate (E. long.): 81º 16.2΄
  • Elevation: 5010 m to 5320 m
  • Administrative location (township): bar ka
  • Administrative location (county): PurangSpu rang
  • Survey expedition: HTCE
  • Survey date: May 8, 2002
  • Contemporary usage: None.
  • Identifiable Buddhist constructions: Manima ṇi walls and gutted shrines.
nodes.title: Basic site data

nodes.body:
The 15 all-stone structures of Lungtsen PukLung bstan phug occupy a narrow gully, amphitheatre, cliffs, and ridgelines sandwiched between the LhachuLha chu and SerlungSer lung valleys of Mount TiséTi se. While the Buddhists undoubtedly occupied this site, it appears to have been founded during the archaic cultural horizon. The adequate shelter offered by these residential structures must have been attractive to Kagyüpabka’ brgyud pa ascetics during heir 12th and 13th CE century colonization of TiséTi se. The do khangrdo khang generally face in a southwesterly direction and are of the same construction, size, setting, and elevation as those found in the vicinity of Gyang DrakGyang grags monastery (B-9). Typically, rear walls were set deep into the slope, giving the buildings a semi-subterranean aspect. The larger specimens (around 8 m x 12 m) have three tiers of rooms or a forward courtyard and two upper tiers of rooms. Smaller specimens generally have two tiers of rooms. The do khangrdo khang were robustly and adeptly constructed from uncut and dressed pieces of brown sandstone, 20 cm to 80 cm in length. The random-rubble walls retain traces of the mud-mortar that once filled the joints.

All do khangrdo khang from RS5 to RS15 are in view of Langa TsoLa lnga mtsho and the Himalaya beyond. At certain times of the year the availability of drinking water may be a problem at Lungtsen PukLung bstan phug, but it seems likely that when the facility was active, water resources were more secure.
nodes.title: General site characteristics

nodes.body: According to natives of Mount TiséTi se (gang riwagangs ri ba), lung btsan phug was a Buddhist retreat center. Elderly gang riwagangs ri ba residents assert that Lungtsen PukLung bstan phug is also known as ShelpukShel phug (Crystal Cave).
nodes.title: Oral tradition

nodes.body: According to Bö Yul Né Gi Lamyik Selwé MikbuBod yul gnas kyi lam yig gsal ba’i dmig bu by khyung dkar sman ri ba slob dpon bstan ‘dzin rnam dag, Tisé Gang Gi ShelpukTi se gangs kyi shel phug was the residence of a nu phrag thag, a prehistoric Zhang ZhungZhang zhung master, who was a chief recipient of Bon teachings.81 He is recorded as residing high up on the south side of TiséTi se. This site is likely to be one and the same as Lungtsen PukLung bstan phug and probably alludes to the archaic residential center located here.
nodes.title: Textual tradition

nodes.body: The do khangrdo khang RS1 is the lowest elevation specimen at Lungtsen PukLung bstan phug (5010 m). This south-facing structure is set on the left side of a gully and is in relatively good condition. It has a pronounced semi-subterranean aspect. Below RS1 are two old walls upon which there are plaques inscribed with he Manima ṇi mantra.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS1

nodes.body: Residential structure RS2 (5020 m) is located directly above RS1. This small edifice may only have had two rooms (east and west). In the west wall of the west room there is a large niche and in the south wall there is a window. There are also a couple in situ bridging stones in the west room. Only fragmentary walls survive in he east room.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS2

nodes.body: Residential structure RS3 is found on the opposite side of the gully from RS1 and RS2, approximately 100 m west of RS2. It was built against a cliff. Only scant structural fragments are left.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS3

nodes.body: Residential structure RS4 (5060 m) was built upon a ledge on the right side of the same gully that hosts RS1, RS2 and RS3. The remains of a central entranceway connect its forward and rear tiers.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS4

nodes.body: Residential structure RS5 (5090 m) is situated on a ridgeline above RS4. It overlooks the LhachuLha chu to the west. This structure appears to have had two forward and two rear rooms. Some corbels and bridging stones are in place as are lintels over the entranceways to the various rooms. In close proximity there is an old Manima ṇi wall and what appears to be the base of a Chörtenmchod rten.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS5

nodes.body: Residential structure RS6 (5080 m) is situated southwest of RS5 on the same ridgeline. Very little of this structure remains intact.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS6

nodes.body: Residential structure RS7 (5130 m) is located at the bottom of the amphitheatre that opens up above the gully in which the lower altitude do khangrdo khang were built. This larger structure with three different levels was built on broad slopes. The lower or forward tier may be that of a courtyard.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS7

nodes.body: Residential structure RS8 (5170) is found on the right or west rim of the amphitheatre. This fairly well-preserved structure was built on a ledge against a cliff, situated just below a ridge-top. The structure appears to have been aligned in the cardinal directions and to have contained three tiers of rooms. The west half of the building has fared much better than the east side. There seems to have been two rear rooms, which still have several in situ bridging stones. The floor-to-ceiling height in these rear rooms was not less than 1.8 m. There is a niche in the rear wall. In between the rear wall and adjoining cliff there is an intervening closed space that may have been used for storage purposes. On the west side of the middle tier there is an interclose and entranceway accessing the rear rooms. The roof over these structures is still intact. A bit of he stone roof has also persisted over the small forward tier west room as well.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS8

nodes.body: Residential structure RS9 (5180 m) was constructed on the ridge-top above RS8. It overlooks the LhachuLha chu. This edifice has been mostly leveled. Nearby, here is a ruined cubic shrine of the type found at other archaic cultural sites.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS9

nodes.body: Residential structure RS10 (5160 m) is found on the right rim of the amphitheatre, east of RS9. This small do khangrdo khang was built on an outcrop. It has been largely destroyed.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS10

nodes.body: Residential structure RS11 (5160 m) was established in the bowl of the amphitheatre against a small cliff. This larger do khangrdo khang probably had three tiers of rooms. Exterior walls and interior partitions are around 1 m in height. The rear wall is supported by the cliff and is 1.5 m in height. A few corbels remain in situ.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS11

nodes.body: Residential structure RS12 (5170 m) was also established in the bowl of the amphitheatre on more open ground. Measuring 8 m x 10 m, it contains three tiers of rooms. Walls up to 1.5 m in height have endured. There is a niche in the rear room and one in the middle room of the west side of the structure.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS12

nodes.body: Residential structure RS13 is located roughly 200 m north of RS12, on the rim of the amphitheatre. It was not visited during the survey.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS13

nodes.body: Residential structure RS14 (5320 m) stands well above the amphitheatre on a cliff, just below the summit of he site. This is a smaller do khangrdo khang with a southeast aspect. A single corbel has survived in place in one of the two rear rooms. Stones were extracted from the structure in order to build a nearby room in the cliff. This probable Buddhist meditation cell exhibits much cruder masonry than the do khangrdo khang.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS14

nodes.body: Residential structure RS15 (5320 m) possesses the same aspect as RS14, but it is slightly better preserved. Evidently, there were two tiers of rooms. Walls up to 1.2 m in height and two large corbels have survived in situ.
nodes.title: Residential Structure RS15
